question: The Governor of a State is appointed by the President on the advice of the
explanation: The Governor is appointed by the President, but as per constitutional convention, this is done on the advice of the Union Cabinet headed by the Prime Minister.

question: The President gives his resignation to the
explanation: According to Article 56(1)(a), the President addresses the resignation letter to the Vice-President.

question: For what period does the Vice President of India hold office?
explanation: The Vice-President holds office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office.

question: Who among the following holds office during the pleasure of the President?
explanation: The Governor of a State holds office during the pleasure of the President (Article 156).

question: Which of the following is not true regarding the payment of the emoluments of the President?
options: They can be reduced during a Financial Emergency.
They are shown separately in the budget.
They are charged on the Contigency Fund of India.
They do nol require any parliament sanction.
explanation: The emoluments of the President are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India, not the Contingency Fund.

question: The total number of members nominated by the President to the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha is
explanation: The President nominates 12 members to Rajya Sabha and (previously) 2 members to Lok Sabha, totaling 14.

question: Which one of the following does not constitute the electoral college for electing the President of India?
options: Elected members of the Legislative Assembly of each state.
Elected members of the Legislative Council
explanation: Members of Legislative Councils do not participate in the Presidential election; only elected members of Lok Sabha, Rajya Sabha, and Legislative Assemblies participate.

question: Council of Ministers in a Parliamentary type of Government can remain in office till it enjoys the support of the
options: Majority of members of the Upper House of Parliament
Majority of the members of the Upper House of parliament
Minority of members of the Lower House
Majority of the members of the Lower House of Parliament
explanation: The Council of Ministers is collectively responsible to the Lok Sabha (Lower House) and remains in power as long as it enjoys majority support there.

question: Which of the following appointments is not made by the President of India?
explanation: The Speaker of the Lok Sabha is elected by the members of the Lok Sabha from amongst themselves, not appointed by the President.

question: Who appoints the Prime Minister of India?
explanation: Under Article 75, the Prime Minister is appointed by the President.

question: The first woman Governor of a state in free India was
explanation: Sarojini Naidu was the first woman to become the Governor of an Indian state (Uttar Pradesh).

question: Minimum age required to contest for Presidentship is
explanation: Article 58 specifies that a person must have completed the age of 35 years to be eligible for election as President.

question: The charge of impeachment against the President of India for his removal can be preferred by
options: Speaker of Lok Sabha and Chairman of Rajya Sabha
explanation: Impeachment proceedings can be initiated in either House of Parliament (Article 61).

question: The Chief Minister of a Union Territory where such a set up exists, is appointed by the
explanation: In Union Territories like Delhi, the Chief Minister is appointed by the President.

question: Who was the first Prime Minister of India?
explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru served as the first Prime Minister of independent India from 1947 to 1964.

question: In case a President dies while in office, the vice President can act as President for a maximum period of
explanation: An election to fill a vacancy in the office of President occurring by reason of death must be held within six months.

question: The Union Council of Ministers consists of
options: Cabinet Ministers, Minister of State and Deputy Ministers
Cabinet Ministers and Chief Ministers of the States
explanation: The Council of Ministers is a three-tier body comprising Cabinet Ministers, Ministers of State, and Deputy Ministers.

question: Who administers the oath of office to the President of India before he enters upon the office?
explanation: The oath of office to the President is administered by the Chief Justice of India.

question: Who among the following enjoys the rank of a Cabinet Minister of the Indian Union?
options: Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission
Secretary to the Government of India
explanation: The Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission (now NITI Aayog) traditionally holds the rank of a Cabinet Minister.

question: A person who is not a member of Parliament can be appointed as a Minister by the President for a maximum period of
explanation: A minister who is not a member of either House for six consecutive months ceases to be a minister (Article 75).

question: When can a President use his discretion in appointing the Prime Minister?
options: When no political party enjoys a clear majority in the Lok Sabha.
Only when the Lok Sabha has been dissolved.
explanation: When no single party or coalition has a clear majority, the President uses discretion to appoint someone who can likely prove a majority.

question: If in a country there happens to be the office of monarchy as well as a Parliamentary form of government this monarch will be called
options: Both Head of the government and State
explanation: In a constitutional monarchy with a parliamentary system (like the UK), the monarch is the formal Head of State.

question: One feature distinguishing the Rajya Sabha from the Vidhan Parishad is
explanation: The Rajya Sabha has a role in the impeachment of the President and Judges, which the State Vidhan Parishad does not.

question: Chief Ministers of all the states are ex-officio members of the
explanation: The Inter-State Council consists of the PM and Chief Ministers of all States to support center-state coordination.

question: Who, among the following, has the final right to sanction the expenditure of public money in India?
explanation: No money can be withdrawn from the Consolidated Fund of India without the President's recommendation and subsequent Parliamentary approval.

question: Which of the following is not an essential qualification for appointment as a Governor?
options: He must not be a member of either House of Parliament.
He should be a domicile of the state to which he is being appointed.
He should be a citizen of India.
He must have completed the age of 35 years
explanation: The Constitution does not require a Governor to be a domicile of the state to which they are appointed; in fact, the convention is usually the opposite.

question: The President nominates 12 members of the Rajya Sabha according to
options: Their performance as office bearers of cultural societies.
The recommendations made by the Vice President.
Their role played in political set up of the country.
Their distinction in the field of science, art, literature and social service.
explanation: Article 80 provides for 12 members to be nominated based on special knowledge or practical experience in Art, Science, Literature, and Social Service.

question: Which Article of the Constitution empowers the President to appoint a Commission to investigate the condition of backward classes?
explanation: Article 340 empowers the President to appoint a commission to investigate the conditions of socially and educationally backward classes.

question: Who can initiate impeachment proceedings against the President of India?
explanation: Impeachment charges can be initiated by either the Lok Sabha or the Rajya Sabha.

question: Who was the member of the Rajya Sabha when first appointed as the Prime Minister of India?
explanation: Indira Gandhi was a member of the Rajya Sabha when she first became Prime Minister in 1966.

question: What is the minimum age for appointment as a Governor?
explanation: A person must be at least 35 years of age to be eligible for appointment as a Governor.

question: Chief Minister of a State is responsible to
explanation: The Council of Ministers with the Chief Minister is collectively responsible to the Legislative Assembly of the State.

question: The administrative and operational control of the Armed Forces is exercised by the
explanation: While the President is the Supreme Commander, administrative control is exercised through the Ministry of Defence.

question: What is the position of a Minister of State in the Central Government?
options: He is a Minister of Central Government but not a member of the Cabinet.
He looks after the interests of the State Cabinet.
He is the nominee of the State Governor.
He is the nominee of the State Cabinet.
explanation: Ministers of State are the second rank of ministers; they are not members of the Cabinet unless specifically invited.

question: Who among the following is directly responsible to Parliament for all matters concerning the Defence Services of India?
explanation: The Union Defence Minister is responsible to Parliament for the functioning and services of the armed forces.

question: How many times the President of India can seek re-election to his post?
explanation: Article 57 states that a person who holds office as President shall be eligible for re-election to that office any number of times.

question: Who among the following has the power to form a new state within the Union of India?
explanation: A bill for forming new states can be introduced in Parliament only on the recommendation of the President.

question: Is the Prime Minister bound to advise the President on matters on which his advice is sought?
options: If the Council of Ministers so desires.
explanation: The Prime Minister and the Council of Ministers are constitutionally required to aid and advise the President.

question: When the Vice President officiates as President he draws the salary of
explanation: When the Vice-President acts as President, he is entitled to the salary and privileges of the President.

question: Who among the following can attend meetings of the Union Cabinet?
explanation: Only Cabinet-rank ministers attend Cabinet meetings as a matter of right.

question: Who among the following has the Constitutional authority to make rules and regulations fixing the number of members of the UPSC?
explanation: The President is empowered to determine the number of members of the Commission and their conditions of service.

question: Under whose advice the President of India declares Emergency under Article 352?
explanation: The President can only proclaim a National Emergency after receiving a written recommendation from the Union Cabinet.

question: Who acts as the President of India when neither the President nor the Vice President is available?
explanation: In the absence of both President and Vice-President, the Chief Justice of India performs the duties of the President.

question: A proclamation of emergency issued under Article 360 must be approved by the Parliament within
explanation: A proclamation of Financial Emergency must be approved by both Houses of Parliament within two months.

question: The Union Council of Ministers is appointed by the
options: President of India according to his discretion
President of India on the advice of the Prime Minister
explanation: Ministers are appointed by the President on the advice of the Prime Minister.

question: The President can proclaim emergency on the written advice of the
explanation: Historically and practically, the advice is communicated by the Prime Minister on behalf of the Cabinet.

question: The Union Council of Ministers is collectively responsible to
explanation: Article 75(3) states that the Council of Ministers shall be collectively responsible to the House of the People (Lok Sabha).

question: Article 78 of the Constitution deals with
options: President's power to get information from the Council of Ministers.
Prime Minister's duty regarding keeping the President informed.
President's power to send advisory messages to the Parliament.
explanation: Article 78 defines the duties of the Prime Minister in furnishing information to the President.

question: The maximum duration for which the Vice President may officiate as the President, is
explanation: Since a new President must be elected within 6 months of a vacancy, the Vice-President can act as President for a maximum of 6 months.

question: The President's Rule in a State can be continued for a maximum period of
explanation: Every proclamation of President's Rule must be approved by Parliament within two months and then lasts for 6 months.

question: The Chairman and members of State Public Service Commission are appointed by the
explanation: The Governor of the state appoints the Chairman and members of the State PSC.

question: When a State Governor dies or resigns, who normally exercises his functions till a new Governor is appointed?
options: Chief Justice of the High Court
A person designated by State Cabinet
explanation: The Chief Justice of the respective State High Court usually performs the duties of the Governor in case of a vacancy.

question: When a financial emergency is proclaimed
options: Union budget will not be presented
Salaries and allowances of any class of employees may be reduced
Repayment of government debts will stop
Payment of salaries to public servants will be postponed
explanation: During a Financial Emergency, the President may issue directions for the reduction of salaries of persons serving the Union or States.

question: Who appoints the Chairman of the UPSC?
explanation: The Chairman and other members of the UPSC are appointed by the President.

question: Which of the following is correct regarding the Governor of a State?
options: He can recommend to the President to impose President's Rule in the State.
No money bill can be introduced in the State Legislature without his prior permission.
He has the power of issuing ordinances when the legislature is not in session.
explanation: All these are constitutional powers vested in the Governor of a state.

question: If the President wants to resign from office, he may do so by writing to the
explanation: The President's resignation letter is addressed to the Vice-President of India.

question: Is the Prime Minister bound to advise is sought?
options: Yes, if the Council of Ministers so desires
explanation: The Prime Minister is constitutionally bound to provide advice and information when requested by the President.

question: The five year term of the President is calculated from the
options: First day of the month following the month he assumes charge
First day of the month he assumes charge
explanation: The President holds office for a term of five years from the date on which he enters upon his office.

question: Who is the ex- officio Chairman of the Council of States?
explanation: The Vice-President of India is the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha (Council of States).

question: Under which Article of the Constitution is the President's rule promulgated on any state in India?
explanation: Article 356 provides for the imposition of President's Rule in a state in case of failure of constitutional machinery.

question: At a time, President's rule can be imposed on a state for a maximum period of
explanation: Beyond one year, President's rule can only be extended under special circumstances (like Emergency or Election Commission certification).

question: The Chairman of the Planning Commission in India is the
explanation: The Prime Minister was the ex-officio Chairman of the Planning Commission (and now NITI Aayog).

question: When Parliament is not in session, the President can promulgate an ordinance which is to be ratified by the Parliament within
options: 6 weeks from the reassembly of Parliament
6 months from the reassembly of the Parliament
6 weeks from the date of issue of ordinance.
3 months from the date of issue of the ordinance.
explanation: An ordinance must be laid before both Houses of Parliament and shall cease to operate at the expiration of six weeks from the reassembly of Parliament.

question: The President of India is elected by an electoral college comprising of
options: Elected members of Lok sabha and state Legislative Assemblies.
Elected member of both Houses of Parliament and State Legislative Assembly
Elected members of both Houses of parliament.
Elected member of State Legislative Assemblies
explanation: The electoral college consists of elected members of both Houses of Parliament and the elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of States.

question: If the office of the President of India falls vacant, within what time should the next president be elected?
explanation: An election to fill the vacancy must be held no later than six months from the date of the vacancy.

question: The President can proclaim a state of emergency in case of
options: Threat to financial stability of the country.
Failure of constitutional machinery in a state.
explanation: The Constitution provides for National Emergency (Art 352), State Emergency (Art 356), and Financial Emergency (Art 360).

question: In the election of the President, the value of the vote of the Lok Sabha members
options: Differs according to the number of votes a member represents.
explanation: The value of an MP's vote is determined by dividing the total value of votes of all state MLAs by the total number of elected MPs.

question: The Indian President is
explanation: The President is the nominal/titular head (De Jure), while the Prime Minister is the real head (De Facto).

question: The minimum age required for becoming the prime Minister of India is
explanation: Since a member of Lok Sabha must be 25 years old, and the PM can be from Lok Sabha, the minimum age is 25.

question: The President may for violation of the Constitution be removed from the office by
explanation: Article 61 provides the procedure for impeachment of the President for 'violation of the Constitution'.

question: In which of the following situations does the President act in his own discretion?
options: In returning a proposal for reconsideration
explanation: The President can send back the advice of the Council of Ministers once for reconsideration.

question: The Prime Minister, Union Cabinet Minister, Chief Minister and Council of Ministers are all members of
explanation: The NDC is presided over by the Prime Minister and includes all Union Cabinet Ministers and Chief Ministers.

question: The President's Rule in a state means that the state is ruled by
options: The Chief Minister nominated by the President
explanation: Under President's Rule, the Governor carries on the administration of the state on behalf of the President.

question: The Chief Minister of a Union Territory whenever such a set up exists, is appointed by
explanation: The Lt. Governor administers the oath and formally appoints the CM in Union Territories.

question: Under what article of the Constitution of India can the President take over the administration of a state?
explanation: Article 356 is the provision for President's Rule in states.

question: The President can make laws through ordinances
options: Only on subjects in the concurrent list
Even when Parliament is in session.
During the recess of the Parliament
explanation: Article 123 empowers the President to promulgate ordinances when either House of Parliament is not in session.

question: Which of the following qualification is not essential for a person to become the Vice- President?
options: He must be qualified for Rajya Sabha.
He must be at least 35 years.
explanation: The Constitution does not prescribe any specific educational qualification (like being a graduate) for the Vice-President.

question: How many types of Emergency have been visualised in the Constitution of India?
explanation: The three types are National Emergency, State Emergency (President's Rule), and Financial Emergency.

question: The impeachment proceedings against the Vice- President can be initiated
explanation: The Vice-President can be removed by a resolution of the Rajya Sabha passed by an effective majority and agreed to by the Lok Sabha.

question: Who appoints the Governor of Jammu and Kashmir?
explanation: The Governor (now Lt. Governor) of J&K is appointed by the President of India.

question: The President of India can be removed from his office by the
explanation: Removal of the President is done through the process of impeachment by the Parliament.

question: If the President returns a Bill and Parliament passes it again in original form, then the President
explanation: If a bill is passed again by the Houses with or without amendment and presented to the President, the President shall not withhold assent.

question: If a Minister loses a no- confidence motion, then
options: Only PM and that Minister resigns.
The whole Council of Ministers resigns
explanation: Collective responsibility means that a vote of no-confidence against one minister is considered a vote against the entire Council of Ministers.

question: The only instance when the President of India exercised his power of veto related to the
explanation: President Zail Singh exercised a pocket veto in 1986 regarding the Indian Post Office (Amendment) Bill.

question: The control of the preparation of electoral rolls for parliament and legislature vests with the
explanation: Article 324 vests the superintendence, direction, and control of elections (including electoral rolls) in the Election Commission.

question: What is contained in the tenth schedule of the constitution?
options: Provision regarding disqualification on grounds of defection
explanation: The Tenth Schedule was added by the 52nd Amendment Act, 1985, to deal with anti-defection.

question: The Election commission holds election for
options: Parliament, State Legislature, President and Vice-President
explanation: The ECI conducts elections for the Union Parliament, State Legislatures, and the offices of President and Vice-President.

question: For Election to the lok sabha, a nomination paper can be field by
options: Any citizen whose name appears in the electoral roll.
explanation: A person must be a registered voter to file a nomination for Lok Sabha elections.

question: In India, political parties are given recognition by
explanation: The Election Commission of India recognizes political parties as National or State parties.

question: The Vice President is elected by an Electoral College consisting of members of
explanation: The electoral college for the Vice-President consists of members of both Houses of Parliament (both elected and nominated).

question: The election commission does not conduct the elections to the
explanation: Elections to Local Bodies (Panchayats and Municipalities) are conducted by the State Election Commissions, not the ECI.

question: The maximum age prescribed for election as president is
explanation: The Constitution specifies a minimum age of 35 but does not prescribe any upper age limit for the President.

question: The power to decide an election petition is vested in the
explanation: Petitions regarding the election of the President/Vice-President go to the Supreme Court, while others go through the ECI/High Courts.

question: To elect the President of India, which election procedure is used?
options: System of proportional representation by means of single transferable vote
explanation: Article 54 and 55 prescribe the single transferable vote system for the Presidential election.

question: In which year were the first general election held in India?
explanation: India's first general elections were held between October 1951 and February 1952.

question: Election to the house of the people and the Legislative Assemblies are conducted on the basis of
explanation: Universal Adult Franchise (Article 326) allows every citizen above 18 to vote.

question: Who appoint the Chief Election Commissioner of India?
explanation: The Chief Election Commissioner and other Election Commissioners are appointed by the President.

question: Which among the following is not a part of the electoral reforms?
explanation: While EVMs are a technical change in the voting process, the others are structural/legal electoral reforms.

question: Recognition to a political party is accorded by
explanation: The Election Commission of India has the power to recognize parties and allot symbols.

question: The Chief Minister of a state in India is not eligible to vote in the Presidential election if
options: He is a member of the Upper House of the State Legislature
He is a caretaker Chief Minister
He is yet to prove his majority
explanation: Only elected members of the Legislative Assembly (Lower House) can vote. Members of the Legislative Council (Upper House) are excluded.
